The years of Genroku are generally considered to be the Golden Age of the Edo period. A century of peace and seclusion created good economic conditions and cultural growth. The nengō Genroku means "Origin of Good Fortune"Jenkins, Donald. (1971). Ukiyo-e Prints and Paintings: the Primitive Period, 1680-1745, p. 21. ==Events of the Genroku era== * 1688 (Genroku 1): Tokugawa shogunate published a code of conduct for funerals (Fuku-kiju-ryō) and for mourning.Smith, Robert et al. (2004). Japanese Culture: Its Development And Characteristics, p. 28. * 16 September 1689 (Genroku 2, 3rd day of the 7th month): Engelbert Kaempfer arrived at Dejima.Screech, Timon. (2006). Secret Memoirs of the Shoguns: Isaac Titsingh and Japan, 1779-1822, p. 73. * 1693 (Genroku 6, 12th month): Arai Hakuseki became the tutor of Tokugawa Ienobu. * 1693 (Genroku 6): The code of conduct for funerals and mourning was changed.Smith, p. 28. * 1695 (Genroku 8, 8th month): The shogunate placed the Japanese character gen (元) on copper coins. * 4 December 1696: Former-Empress Meishō died at age 74. * 1697 (Genroku 10): The 4th official map of Japan was made.Traganeou, Jilly. (2004). The Tokaido Road: Traveling and Representation in Edo and Meiji Japan, p. 230. * 1697 (Genroku 10): Great fire in Edo. * 1698 (Genroku 11): Another great fire in Edo. * 1703 (Genroku 16, 3rd month): Ōishi Yoshio commits seppuku. * 1703 (Genroku 16, 5th month): First performance of Chikamatsu Monzaemon's play The Love Suicides at Sonezaki (Sonezaki shinjū). * 31 December 1703 (Genroku 16, 23rd day of the 11th month): The Great Genroku Earthquake shook Edo. Fire spread in the city.
